title: Enrique Reneau
text:
Germán Enrique Centeno Reneau, known as “Quique” Renau (9 April 1971 – 23 August 2015) was a Honduran <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player.
Club career.
A lightning fast striker and nicknamed "El Esquilete" (the Stilletto) or "La Gacela" (the Gazelle), Reneau started his career at <a href="C.D.%20Victoria">Victoria</a> where he debuted in 1989. He went on to score 37 goals with <a href="C.D.%20Victoria">Victoria</a> between 1990 and 1996, as well in 2000. At Victoria he was an important member of their first league title-winning team in <a href="1994-95%20Honduran%20Liga%20Nacional">1995</a> when scoring the goal that won them the championship against <a href="C.D.%20Olimpia">Olimpia</a> in <a href="Tegucigalpa">Tegucigalpa</a>.
Later he played for <a href="C.D.%20Marath%C3%B3n">Marathón</a>, <a href="C.D.%20Olimpia">Olimpia</a>, <a href="Real%20C.D.%20Espa%C3%B1a">Real España</a> and <a href="C.D.S.%20Vida">Vida</a>, winning the <a href="1998-99%20Honduran%20Liga%20Nacional">1999 Apertura</a> with <a href="C.D.%20Olimpia">Olimpia</a> and the <a href="2001-02%20Honduran%20Liga%20Nacional">2002 Clausura</a> with <a href="C.D.%20Marath%C3%B3n">Marathón</a>. From 1990 to 2004, Reneau scored 59 goals in total in the <a href="Liga%20Nacional%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Profesional%20de%20Honduras">Liga Nacional</a>. In the <a href="2001-02%20Honduran%20Liga%20Nacional">2001 Apertura</a> he was the league's top goalscorer with 8 goals. He was never sent off in his career.
Spells abroad.
He also had a stint in Peru with Sipesa and in El Salvador with <a href="Cojutepeque%20F.C.">Cojutepeque</a> and <a href="C.D.%20Luis%20%C3%81ngel%20Firpo">Luis Ángel Firpo</a> whom he left for Mexican side <a href="Cruz%20Azul%20Hidalgo">Cruz Azul Hidalgo</a>. He returned to El Salvador in August 2005 to play for <a href="C.D.%20Chalatenango">Chalatenango</a>.
He finished his career at Guatemalan side <a href="Deportivo%20Mictl%C3%A1n">Mictlán</a> with whom he won promotion to the Guatemalan top tier in summer 2006.
International career.
Reneau made his debut for <a href="Honduras%20national%20football%20team">Honduras</a> in a January <a href="1996%20CONCACAF%20Gold%20Cup">1996 CONCACAF Gold Cup</a> match against <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> and has earned a total of 16 caps, scoring 5 goals. He has represented his country in 5 <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> matches and played at the <a href="1997%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1997 UNCAF Nations Cup</a>, as well as at the <a href="1996%20CONCACAF%20Gold%20Cup">1996 CONCACAF Gold Cup</a>.
His final international was an April <a href="1997%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1997 UNCAF Nations Cup</a> match against <a href="Panama%20national%20football%20team">Panama</a>.
Retirement, personal life and death.
His parents were Óscar Centeno and María Carolina Reneau. He met his Salvadoran girlfriend Brenda Ramírez in 1996, when he played for Firpo. Reneau has three children: Melissa, Karen and Enrique. After retiring in 2006 he moved to New Orleans and then Miami in the United States where he painted buildings.
In July 2013, Reneau was diagnosed with motor neurone disease. He subsequently lost his job in the US and returned to Honduras in December 2013. He died on 23 August 2015 in a La Ceiba's Vicente Dantoni hospital due to respiratory failure.
